slides.title: Administering workers’ compensation
slides.ocrText: Administering workers’ compensation

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe the setup and administration

process of jurisdictional benefit parameters
Describe the setup and administration
process of managing ICD codes

Set up denial periods for jurisdictions

Set up and administer PPD parameters

Set up search columns and default loss types
for users

| Lesson outline

Workers’ compensation setup basics

slides.title: Workers’ compensation setup
slides.ocrText:
Workers’ compensation setup
basics

slides.title: ClaimCenter setup for WC background
slides.originalNotes:
ClaimCenter setup for WC background
NOTE: This lesson primarily describes administration tasks you can perform in ClaimCenter. Configuration tasks in Guidewire Studio are not needed to perform many of the administration tasks described.

The example rates and parameters provided in this lesson are meant as samples for illustrative purposes only.
slides.notes:
ClaimCenter setup for WC background
NOTE: This lesson primarily describes administration tasks you can perform in ClaimCenter. Configuration tasks in Guidewire Studio are not needed to perform many of the administration tasks described.

The example rates and parameters provided in this lesson are meant as samples for illustrative purposes only.
slides.ocrText:
| ClaimCenter setup for WC background Gi

• To implement the WC Line of Business (LOB), key administration tasks are
required. Most of them are related to:

Benefit calculations for Time Loss Exposures
Compensability Decision Activity

PPD (Permanent Partial Disability) calculations
ICD-10 codes

• Note: ClaimCenter sample data provides administration parameters as examples
only

Many parameters are out of date

Some parameters may not be included for some jurisdictions

Consult with official state board guidelines for official WC rates

It is assumed that, during an implementation, many WC parameters will be created, updated, or added

slides.title: ClaimCenter WC Administration screens
slides.originalNotes:
ClaimCenter WC Administration screens
Only users with the appropriate permissions have access to the Administration screen. From there, WC Parameters are accessed by navigating to Business Settings > WC Parameters. The WC Parameters menu link contains four child menu links: Benefit Parameters : Provides a list of jurisdictions. Clicking a jurisdiction opens the Benefit Parameters Detail screen showing the set of benefit parameters for that jurisdictiom PPD Min I Max: Provides datasimilar to the PPD area of the Benefit Parameter Detail screen, but with more detail

PPD Weeks: Entry screen in which you can define the limits of how long the injured worker canreceive the workers’ compensation benefits, based on the disability.

Compensability Parameters: Shows a list of jurisdictions and the maximum time for each that the insurer has to make a compensability decision, the denial period. Click a jurisdiction to open its Compensability Parameter Detail page, where you can edit the settings.
slides.notes:
ClaimCenter WC Administration screens
Only users with the appropriate permissions have access to the Administration screen. From there, WC Parameters are accessed by navigating to Business Settings > WC Parameters. The WC Parameters menu link contains four child menu links: Benefit Parameters : Provides a list of jurisdictions. Clicking a jurisdiction opens the Benefit Parameters Detail screen showing the set of benefit parameters for that jurisdictiom PPD Min I Max: Provides datasimilar to the PPD area of the Benefit Parameter Detail screen, but with more detail

PPD Weeks: Entry screen in which you can define the limits of how long the injured worker canreceive the workers’ compensation benefits, based on the disability.

Compensability Parameters: Shows a list of jurisdictions and the maximum time for each that the insurer has to make a compensability decision, the denial period. Click a jurisdiction to open its Compensability Parameter Detail page, where you can edit the settings.

slides.title: Benefit parameters
slides.originalNotes:
Benefit parameters
An important aspect of handling workers' compensation claims is calculating workers’ compensation payments for lost time. The following calculation is an example of a possible TPD(Temporary Partial Disability) calculation using AWW (Amount Weekly Wage):

WeeklyCompRate = JurisdictionR ate x (Pre-injuryA WW - Post- injuryA

It is possible for a state to calculate this value differently for each year. In the base configuration, ClaimCenter provides sample calculations for a few example states and more detailed sample PPD calculations for the state of California. The goal of these examples is to show you how you can calculate these amounts.
You enter, manage, and edit various workers' compensation- related parameters through the ClaimCenter interface. ClaimCenter then uses these parameters to perform the actual calculations. An adjuster can always override workers' comp amounts by entering a manual amount.
slides.notes:
Benefit parameters
An important aspect of handling workers' compensation claims is calculating workers’ compensation payments for lost time. The following calculation is an example of a possible TPD(Temporary Partial Disability) calculation using AWW (Amount Weekly Wage):

WeeklyCompRate = JurisdictionR ate x (Pre-injuryA WW - Post- injuryA

It is possible for a state to calculate this value differently for each year. In the base configuration, ClaimCenter provides sample calculations for a few example states and more detailed sample PPD calculations for the state of California. The goal of these examples is to show you how you can calculate these amounts.
You enter, manage, and edit various workers' compensation- related parameters through the ClaimCenter interface. ClaimCenter then uses these parameters to perform the actual calculations. An adjuster can always override workers' comp amounts by entering a manual amount.
slides.ocrText:
| Benefit parameters G&G

• Used to calculate payments for lost time
* Contain jurisdiction, start date, and end date

* Sets benefit rates for a specific time period

+ Claims that have a Time Loss exposure matching a jurisdiction and start/end date for the parameter
use the rates on that parameter

* Conditions such as applying minimums and maximums may be used

Sample data provides sample parameters for 15 U.S. states

Note: All sample data is for illustrative purposes only and does not reflect actual rates as
prescribed by law.

=.5B 9b B

slides.title: Benefit parameters: definitions
slides.originalNotes:
Benefit parameters: definitions
ClaimCenter can calculate benefits, for example, as Average Weekly Wage (AWW) times the Percent of Wages. If the result falls within the maximum and minimum, this calculated benefit amount becomes the benefit. Otherwise, the value is set to either the maximum or theminimum depending on the calculated value.

If you set Minimum adjusted by Weekly Wage to Yes and the employee's AWW is less than the Minimum Weekly Benefit, the Calculation changes. The minimum amount that the worker can receive becomes the AWWrather than the Minimum Weekly Benefit

For most jurisdictions, the percent of wages is usually two- thirds.

The Maximum and Minimum weekly benefit rates are usually raised every year or so to account for inflation/cost of livingincreases. Therefore, there are
rows in the Admin screen pertaining to each year (for California). Alternatively, you may alter the startlend dates accordingly if you want your parameters to apply for a longer period of time.

Minimum adjusted by Weekly Wage is a yes/no value that handles cases where the AWW is below the minimum. If yes, the AVMW is used. If no, the minimum weekly benefit is used.
slides.notes:

rows in the Admin screen pertaining to each year (for California). Alternatively, you may alter the startlend dates accordingly if you want your parameters to apply for a longer period of time.

Minimum adjusted by Weekly Wage is a yes/no value that handles cases where the AWW is below the minimum. If yes, the AVMW is used. If no, the minimum weekly benefit is used.
slides.ocrText:
Benefit parameters: definitions

All four benefit types (TTD, TPD, PTD, and PPD)
in ClaimCenter come with four “basic”
parameters/rates:

Percent of Wages (decimal): Usually 67%
(two-thirds)

Maximum Weekly Benefit ($): Sets maximum
payout imposed by that jurisdiction.

Minimum Weekly Benefit ($): Sets minimum
payout imposed by that jurisdiction.

Minimum adjusted by Weekly Wage: Yes/No

slides.title: Example: Time Loss exposure with no parameters [5
slides.originalNotes:
Example: Time Loss exposure with no parameters
ClaimCenter displays the results of the benefit calculations as benefits amounts in the Time Loss > Benefits card of a workers' compensation claim. If This screen provides a view of any calculated values for each of the four benefit types. The screen shows any benefit factors relevant to the claim as well. It is possible to edit this screen and enter a weekly compensation rate manually.

If there is no entry in Benefit Parameter appropriate for the claim, ClaimCenter sets the value of Reference Data for that benefit type to Not available.

If ClaimCenter cannot calculate the Compensation Rate, meaning that CompRate == null, thenClaimCenter generates a Not available message.
slides.notes:

If ClaimCenter cannot calculate the Compensation Rate, meaning that CompRate == null, thenClaimCenter generates a Not available message.

slides.title: Matching claim data to WC benefit parameters fa
slides.originalNotes:
Matching claim data to WC benefit parameters
The "Impairment Rating" is matched to the EDisability % “ value in the WC Admin parameters for PPD.

The Amount Weekly Wage (AWW) is crucial for TTD, PTD and PPD calculations because each benefit type usually calculates a EO/o of wages" (the •wages" being AWW). For TPD the "wages" usually is the differential between Pre and Post Injury eamings.
slides.notes:
Matching claim data to WC benefit parameters
The "Impairment Rating" is matched to the EDisability % “ value in the WC Admin parameters for PPD.

The Amount Weekly Wage (AWW) is crucial for TTD, PTD and PPD calculations because each benefit type usually calculates a EO/o of wages" (the •wages" being AWW). For TPD the "wages" usually is the differential between Pre and Post Injury eamings.
slides.ocrText:
| Matching claim data to WC benefit parameters fa

“State of Jurisdiction” on Loss Details matches the Jurisdiction WC parameter

“Loss date’ (or “notice date”) of claim falls between start/end dates in WC
parameter

“Impairment Rating” on Time Loss exposure matches the PPD Weeks WC
parameter (Disability %) (for PPD)

If the following data is provided, the “weekly comp rate” is automatically calculated:

Weekly Wage (Pre-Injury) (AWW)
Weekly Wage Amount (Post-Injury) (for TPD)

slides.title: Other jurisdictional factors
slides.originalNotes:
Other jurisdictional factors
The "other" jurisdictional factors shown are provided as-is in the base application Florida doesindeed have unique laws when it comes to Workers' Comp, as do several other states/jurisdictions such as New Jersey, Texas, Pennsylvania and California.

Rules with a Category of "Override" in them in the base product sample data will have associated Gosu code to programmatically apply the overrides to the benefits. Consult with your implementation team regarding the specifics of how this code can be configured

slides.title: Impairment rating and disability percentage fa
slides.originalNotes:
Impairment rating and disability percentage
While PPD can apply to workers that have lost an appendage or limb, it is also common in situations where an IW cannot perform physical functions as well as they did prior to the injury. Often, the impairment rating could apply to the "whole body". It does not necessarily mean that 30% of a particular limb's use has been lost, but rather the workerhas lost 30% of their overall capacity for physical function. In addition to setting a "number of weeks" based on an impairment rating, PPD minimax benefits are capped using two sets of minimax benefit values:
1. Minimax rates for impairment ratings of 1% - 69%
2. Minimax rates for impairment ratings of - 99%
slides.notes:
Impairment rating and disability percentage
While PPD can apply to workers that have lost an appendage or limb, it is also common in situations where an IW cannot perform physical functions as well as they did prior to the injury. Often, the impairment rating could apply to the "whole body". It does not necessarily mean that 30% of a particular limb's use has been lost, but rather the workerhas lost 30% of their overall capacity for physical function. In addition to setting a "number of weeks" based on an impairment rating, PPD minimax benefits are capped using two sets of minimax benefit values:
1. Minimax rates for impairment ratings of 1% - 69%
2. Minimax rates for impairment ratings of - 99%
slides.ocrText:
| Impairment rating and disability percentage fa

PPD is calculated using an “impairment rating” in addition to the “standard” 67% of
AWW

This is because PPD is subject to jurisdiction limits including the number of weeks
and maximum benefit amount

The impairment rating quantifies the I|W’s permanent disability and sets the
maximum number of weeks for which an IW is paid

Impairment rating is also known as a “disability percentage”

Because the worker has limited capacity to work, the purpose is to compensate for
that limited capacity (example: “The impairment is 20% because the doctor has
determined that you have lost some ability to move your right arm”)

slides.title: PPD administration parameters
slides.originalNotes:
PPD administration parameters
The volume of parameters for PPD (notice there are 20 pages of PPD weeks parameters) is much larger because of the very precise nature of calculating a benefit. Not only must you know the "Impairment Rating", you must match that impairment rating to a unique of weeks“ and determine the min/max either in the 1-69% bracket or 70-99% bracket. A disability percentage of 1% means 3 weeks of PPD, 2% means 6 weeks, 3% 9 weeks, and so on (all the way to 99%).
slides.notes:
PPD administration parameters
The volume of parameters for PPD (notice there are 20 pages of PPD weeks parameters) is much larger because of the very precise nature of calculating a benefit. Not only must you know the "Impairment Rating", you must match that impairment rating to a unique of weeks“ and determine the min/max either in the 1-69% bracket or 70-99% bracket. A disability percentage of 1% means 3 weeks of PPD, 2% means 6 weeks, 3% 9 weeks, and so on (all the way to 99%).

slides.title: Compensability decision
slides.originalNotes:
Compensability decision
The compensability decision, indicated in the Loss Details screen, involves determining if a workers compensation claim is valid and hence, payable. There are several factors to consider when determining compensability. For example, an adjuster can ask a series of questions, such as, e Was safety equipment used?" or•was the person using illegal substances?" The adjuster alsoneeds to determine if the incidentwas accidental in nature or in the course of employment, or if there was jurisdiction. Jurisdiction addresses time, place, and employment relationship.
slides.notes:

The adjuster alsoneeds to determine if the incidentwas accidental in nature or in the course of employment, or if there was jurisdiction. Jurisdiction addresses time, place, and employment relationship.

slides.title: Compensability parameters: denial period
slides.originalNotes:
Compensability parameters: denial period
A denial period is the time in which an insurer must respond to a new WC claim. During that period, they must either accept or deny the claim. ClaimCenter creates a Determine Compensability activity with due and escalation dates based on the compensability parameters. Ifthere is not a matching parameter, the activity is created using the activity pattern arguments. In the base application, the target date is plus 5 days and the escalation date is plus 7 days.

If jurisdictional data is not available, there is a note in the description of the activity stating that jurisdictional data is incomplete.

The compensability parameter includes the target days and a denial period formula. The formula determines if the target date is calculated from the loss date, the notice date, or the greater of the two. The target dates on this slide are just examples.
slides.notes:

Ifthere is not a matching parameter, the activity is created using the activity pattern arguments. In the base application, the target date is plus 5 days and the escalation date is plus 7 days.

If jurisdictional data is not available, there is a note in the description of the activity stating that jurisdictional data is incomplete.

The compensability parameter includes the target days and a denial period formula. The formula determines if the target date is calculated from the loss date, the notice date, or the greater of the two. The target dates on this slide are just examples.

slides.title: Adding and editing ICD codes =
slides.originalNotes:
Adding and editing ICD codes
The set of ICD-IO codes is not final. Updates to ICD-IO codesare published by CMS (U.S. Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services) annually. An administrator has the ability to add new codes (as shown) or work to import the codes through Configuratiom

In addition, the ICD-IO standard reflects all medical research and medical advances worldwide. Therefore, it is possible that ICD itself may add codes in the future if a new disease, ailment or illness is identified.

Administrative users may add or edit ICD codes. To add a code, click Add new code. To edit a code, click the code number in the list. Note that codes cannot be deleted in the base application.

According to the World Health Organization, ICD-II will be released in 2018.
slides.notes:

Administrative users may add or edit ICD codes. To add a code, click Add new code. To edit a code, click the code number in the list. Note that codes cannot be deleted in the base application.

According to the World Health Organization, ICD-II will be released in 2018.

slides.title: User settings
slides.ocrText: User settings

slides.title: Sort by injured worker
slides.originalNotes:
Sort by injured worker
With the LossType set to Workers' Comp, you may sort in ascending or descending order by the Injured Worker's last name.

Users without this setting will see the column with the header Claimant. For other lines of business (Personal Auto, Homeowners, and so on), there may be multiple claimants, and therefore sorting on this columnbecomes meaningless.
slides.notes:
Sort by injured worker
With the LossType set to Workers' Comp, you may sort in ascending or descending order by the Injured Worker's last name.

Users without this setting will see the column with the header Claimant. For other lines of business (Personal Auto, Homeowners, and so on), there may be multiple claimants, and therefore sorting on this columnbecomes meaningless.

slides.title: Default policy type

Default policy type
This setting is for convenience and ease of use only. It does not effectively prevent a user from creating a claim or finding policies on a different LOB.

Administering workers’ compensation

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
Which parameter can set the Determine Compensability activity’s due
date on a claim?
•
A) Jurisdictional Benefit Parameter
B) PPD Min/Max
C) Waiting Period
D) Denial Period

questionData.question:
Which parameter can set the Determine Compensability activity’s due
date on a claim?
A) Jurisdictional Benefit Parameter
B) PPD Min/Max
C) Waiting Period
D) Denial Period
questionData.answer:
A) Jurisdictional Benefit Parameter
B) PPD Min/Max
C) Waiting Period
D) Denial Period

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer a
Which parameter can set the Determine Compensability activity’s due
date on a claim?
74
A) Jurisdictional Benefit Parameter
B) PPD Min/Max
C) Waiting Period
D) Denial Period
Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
What is the purpose of an impairment rating on a claim? How is this
matched to admin parameters?

questionData.question:
What is the purpose of an impairment rating on a claim? How is this
matched to admin parameters?
questionData.answer:
An impairment rating specifies, for PPD, the degree of disability or loss of use the IW
has suffered as part of a permanent disability. It is matched to two admin parameters:
the PPD Min/Max and the PPD # of weeks (for a given jurisdiction and effective
start/end dates)

slides.ocrText:
Answer a

•
•

start/end dates)

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
'fyou want to calculate a TTD weekly comp rate, what data on a claim
must exist to match admin parameters?
•

questionData.question:
If you want to calculate a TTD weekly comp rate, what data on a claim
must exist to match admin parameters?
questionData.answer:
Three pieces of data:
1. The state (jurisdiction)
2. The claim’s loss date or notice date
3. The worker's AWW.
